awd_titl_txt: Travel Support for Participants in the 2016 New Security Paradigms Workshop
awd_abstract_narration: This award will support student travel to the 2016 New Security Paradigms Workshop to be held in Colorado in September 2016. The New Security Paradigms Workshop (NSPW) provides a stimulating, safe, and highly interactive forum for innovative approaches to computer security. NSPW encourages graduate students and junior faculty to examine long-held ideas within computer security. It also strongly encourages non-computer security experts from economics, sociology, psychology, and other disciplines to bring their expertise to bear on computer security paradigms. The support from NSF will be used to sponsor travel expenses for graduate students and junior faculty to attend the workshop. Supporting junior researchers' travel to attend professional conferences and workshops is a very important mission of the NSF. Broader impacts include training the next generation of researchers in this important research area.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Computer security is a serious problem. The New Security Paradigms Workshop (NSPW) provides a stimulating, safe, and highly interactive forum for innovative approaches to computer security. New participants interact constructively with the most experienced researchers in the field, exploring paradigm shifts that disrupt the status quo, destroy outdated ideas, and open the way to new security technologies, techniques, and procedures. NSPW has already made many significant breakthroughs. The workshop has always been inclusive. The Call for Papers is internationally distributed and invites everyone to submit a paper describing a new security paradigm. The papers are selected on merit, and financial aid for attendees is granted based on need. Attendees and organizers comprise a diverse group from many nations and the significant female/minority presence is unusual in such a highly technical field. The workshop papers are published by ACM and are available worldwide on ACM’s Digital Library.

NSPW strongly encourages graduate students and junior faculty to examine long-held ideas within computer security. It also strongly encourages non-computer security experts from other disciplines such as economics, sociology, psychology, and other disciplines to bring their expertise to bear on computer security paradigms. This impacts fields other than computer science, and also expands our understanding of both information assurance and computer security as well as how people, organizations, societies, and other entities affect, and are affected by, computer security considerations.

NSPW accepts papers that challenge existing paradigms and develop new ones, and then helps the authors expand upon them and develop them further through an intensely interactive workshop. As a result, ideas first discussed at NSPW have gained widespread acceptance and have appeared fully developed, in archival journals.

This grant supported students and junior faculty who are invited to attend this workshop. Students had the highest priority, as they are new to the field, and attending and presenting at the workshop encouraged them to propose new paradigms or to challenge existing ones in a very supportive, interactive environment. This grant, for example, supported travel and registration for 2 graduate students and 4 junior faculty members, as well as registration for a fifth junior faculty member, all of whom presented papers, or participated in panels and were on the program committee, and chaired sessions, at the workshop.


Last Modified: 08/09/2019
Modified by: Matt Bishop
